title: Why 97 companies are opposing Trump’s travel ban
text:
WATCH: Melissa McCarthy plays Sean Spicer on ‘SNL’ 
By Joseph Pisani, The Associated Press 
NEW YORK — Apple, Google and more than 90 other companies are pushing back in court against President Donald Trump’s temporary travel ban, calling it unconstitutional, un-American and bad for the economy. 
The companies filed briefs Sunday to back lawsuits from Washington and Minnesota fighting Trump’s travel ban. The ban keeps refugees and travelers from seven Muslim-majority countries from entering the U.S. 
Trump has said his Jan. 27 executive order is necessary to prevent “radical Islamic terrorists” from coming to the U.S. The White House did not respond to a request for comment Monday. 
Attorneys general from 15 states, including California, Illinois, Pennslvania and Virginia, and the District of Columbia on Monday urged a federal appeals court to uphold the lower court judge’s stay on Trump’s immigration order. 
The 97 companies are mostly in the technology industry and include Apple, Facebook, Google, Microsoft, Facebook and Twitter. Non-tech companies participating include yogurt maker Chobani, eyeglass brand Warby Parker and jeans-seller Levi Strauss & Co. 
Here’s some of the reasons why the companies oppose the travel ban: 
It hurts the economy 
Immigrants will avoid the U.S. and want to work in other countries where “their immigration status will not suddenly be revoked,” the companies argued. They also said the ban makes it more likely that big companies will move employees overseas or make investments outside the U.S. 
“Ultimately, American workers and the economy will suffer as a result,” the companies said.
